newsitem.title: UK: IBCA affirms Belgium's AA+ longterm rating.
newsitem.headline: IBCA affirms Belgium's AA+ longterm rating.

text.p: European credit rating agency IBCA on Wednesday affirmed its AA+ long-term foreign currency rating for Belgium.
It said this applied to senior and unsecured sovereign debt issues and sets a ceiling for all other Belgian issuers.
IBCA also affirmed its A1+ rating for Belgian short term issues and AAA for local currency issues.

The agency said Belgium, a member of the European Union's Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) since the late 1970s, had a record of low inflation and currency stability that made it a likely candidate for the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).
"With inflation around two percent and a general government deficit close to the required three percent, the only question mark concerns the level of public debt," IBCA said in a statement.
"Unfortunately at 134 percent of GDP last year this is not only more than double the Maastricht limit but far higher than that of any other potential EMU member."
It said the government's austerity programme was a positive sign but slow growth, high unemployment and an ageing population were complicating any progress.

"Although public finances are less vulnerable to an interest rate shock than in the early 1990s, much will depend on the government's ability to sustain a sufficiently large primary surplus until well after 1999," IBCA swaid.
It said the introduction of bonds with longer maturities had deepened the market for Belgian government debt and made it more attractive to external investors.
"The capital account remains sensitive to interest and exchange rate movements but recent financial market reforms have increased the attractiveness of BEF assets for external investors," IBCA said
It said thanks partly to constitutional reforms, Flemish separatism was no longer a serious threat.
"The recent scandal over political involvement in the judiciary is likely to prompt a reform of the legal system but should not endanger the unity of the state."
